children.name: money that you make by doing business
profit b2
children.definition: profit/ˈprɒfɪt, ˈprɒfətǁˈprɑː-/  money that you make by doing business, for example when you sell something for more that it cost you to buy it or to produce it:
examples: lợi nhuận
▪ we aim to increase our profits by at least 5% every year.
▪ for the first time, the company’s annual profits were over $1 million.
▪ they don’t care who they sell weapons to. all they are interested in is profit.
make a profit : kiến được lợi nhuận
▪ they made a huge profit when they sold the business.
profitnounlợi nhuận, lời lãi; tiền lãi, tiền lời
[ c or u ] money which is earned in trade or business, especially after paying the costs of producing and selling goods and services
_shemakesa big profit from selling waste material to textile companies.
_a year ago thetokyocompany had apretaxprofit of 35 million yen.
_company profits are down on last year's figures.
_you don't expect to make much profit within the first couple of years of setting up a company.
he sold his houseat ahuge profit.

children.name: proceeds x
children.definition: proceeds/ˈprəʊsiːdz/  all the money that you get from selling something, or from something such as a show or a sports event:
examples: số tiền thu được, hoa lợi
▪ his first year in business was so successful that john could afford to buy a delivery van with the proceeds.
▪ the proceeds of the sale of the house went to an animal-welfare charity, as stated in the owner’s will.
proceedsplural noun( proceeds of / from something) tiền thu được (do bán hàng, trình diễn....)
the amount of money received from a particular
event or activity or when something is sold
_theproceedsoftoday's festival will go to several local charities.
_it says on the back of the card 'all proceeds to charity'.

children.name: surplus x
children.definition: surplus/ˈsɜːʳpləs/  the amount of money that remains after a company or organization has paid all its costs, charges, wages etc:
examples: lợi nhuận
▪ our surplus on book publishing last year was $47 million.
▪ for the first time in 20 years congress was working with a budget surplus.

children.name: gain c1
children.definition: gain/geɪn/  the profit that someone makes - use this especially when you think that thepersonorcompanymaking the profit is only interested in getting money or anadvantage forthemselves:
examples: lợi nhuận ( mang tính cá nhân )
for gainin order to make a profit
▪ if private hospitals are operating purely for gain, how can we be sure they have the patients’ best interests at heart?
short-term gaina situation in which profits may be made for a short time, but which may cause losses and problems in the future
▪ companies just don’t invest enough -- short-term gain is all they think about.

children.name: a profit from leaving money in the bank or lending it to a company
return x
children.definition: return/rɪˈtɜːʳn/  thetotalprofitthat you get as a result of putting money into a bank, company etc -used especially in business:
examples: lợi nhuận ( từ việc đầu tư vốn, chứ không phải kinh doanh )
▪ the company offers the hope of big returns for people who buy its shares.return on an investment
▪ the return on the initial investment was huge.

children.name: yield x
children.definition: yield/jiːld/  theexactamountof profit that you get as a result of lending money to a company, government etc -used especially in business:
examples: lợi xuất , lợi tức ( từ việc đầu tư vốn, chứ không phải kinh doanh )
▪ we have calculated the probable yield from this investment at around 17%.
▪ if you invest the money now, the yield after only twelve months will be $3160.

children.name: make a profit b2
children.definition: make a profit/ˌmeɪk ə ˈprɒftǁ-ˈprɑː-/  to get a profit from abusinessor fromsellingsomething:
examples: kiếm lời, kiếm lãi
▪ harry made a good profit - he bought the house for £45,000 and sold it for £55,000 six months later.
▪ when you consider how much this meal would cost to prepare at home, you realize that the restaurant must be making an enormous profit.
make a profit of $53m/£600 etc
▪ the drug company sasco made a profit of $53 million last year.
make a profit on
▪ even though the price has been reduced, the builders will still make a profit on the sale.

children.name: make a killing x
children.definition: make a killing/ˌmeɪk ə ˈkɪlɪŋ/ informalto get a very large profit quickly from one successfulbusinessdeal:
examples: kiếm được số tền lớn
▪ he had made a killing on the stock exchange that morning.
▪ vito’s a debonair middle-aged new yorker, who’s made a killing in advertising.

children.name: the amount of sth that is sold
business u
children.definition: business/ˈbɪznɪs, ˈbɪznəs/  a company is successful/not successful
examples: công việc kinh doanh ( thành công hay thất bại )
▪ business is really bad at the moment. they may have to sell some of their factories overseas.
▪ business was good until june and then sales fell because people were on vacation.
business is boomingbusiness is very good
▪ in the old days, when business was booming, he used to fly to new york twice a week.
something is good for business
▪ building the new highway will be good for business.
business/ ˈbɪz.nɪs /noun(work)
[ u ] the amount of work done or the number of goods or services sold by a company or organization:
business is good/brisk/booming/flourishing(= i'm selling a lot).
business is bad/slack/quiet(= i'm not selling much).
how is business(= are you selling much)at the moment?

children.name: sales b2
children.definition: sales/seɪlz/  the number of products that a business sells, or the value of the products it sells:
examples: doanh thu
▪ a big price increase led to a fall in sales.
sales of
▪ sales of the book have been astonishing.
▪ coupons for discounts on certain products have increased sales of those products.
sales/seɪlz/ [plural noun] the amount of goods or services that a company sells:
▪ sales have been far better than expected.
▪ these firms report sales of between 10 and 20 million dollars a year.
sales figuresinformation about how much has been sold
▪ december sales figures will be released on thursday.
sales lượng hàng hoá bán được; doanh thu
the number of products sold
_sales this year exceeded the total for the two previous years.

children.name: turnover c1
children.definition: turnover/ˈtɜːʳnˌəʊvəʳ/  the value of goods or services that a company sells over a particular period of time:
examples: doanh số, doanh thu
▪ turnover at the two restaurants was about $7.4 million this year.
▪ recently the company has been trying to increase its turnover by diversifying into other fields.
turnover/ˈtɜːʳnəʊvəʳ/ [singular noun] the amount of goods or services that a company sells in a particular period of time:
▪ our corporation has an annual turnover of $3.2 billion.
▪ turnover is expected to double now that the recession is over.
turnovernounbusinessdoanh số; doanh thu
[ c or u ] the amount of business that a company does in a period of time
_large supermarkets havehighturnovers (= their goods sell very quickly) .
_the business has anannualturnover of £50 000.

children.name: not mean to make a profit
non-profitmaking x
children.definition: non-profitmaking/nɒn ˈprɒftmeɪkɪŋǁnɑːn ˈprɑː-/  british a company or business that is non-profitmaking does business so that its profits are used to provide money for hospitals, poor people etc:
examples: phi lợi nhuận
▪ traidcraft is a non-profitmaking organization that buys goods from indian workers at fair prices.
non-profit(-making)adjective(mainly usnonprofit)
describes an organization which does not make a profit, usually intentionally
_charities are non-profit-making organizations and get tax relief.

children.name: when a business produces a profit
money-spinner x
children.definition: money-spinner/ˈmʌni ˌspɪnəʳ/  britishinformalabusinessorproductthat produces a large profit:
examples: thứ hái ra tiền, sản phẩm hái ra tiền
▪ the little bar turned out to be a real moneyspinner.
▪ the toy companies are always trying to find another money-spinner like monopoly or the barbie doll.

children.name: profitable b2
children.definition: profitable/ˈprɒfɪtəbəl, ˈprɒfətəbəlǁˈprɑː-/  a profitablebusinessoractivitymakes a profit:
examples: có lời, có lãi
▪ we don’t sell children’s clothes any more - it wasn’t
profitable enough.
▪ it’s only in the last year that our business has become profitable. before that we were just managing to cover our costs.

children.name: lucrative c2
children.definition: lucrative/ˈluːkrətɪv/  a type ofbusinessoractivitythat is lucrative produces a verylargeprofit:
examples: sinh lợi nhiều
▪ catering is a very lucrative business if you succeed in it.
▪ sam’s journalistic work was much more lucrative than his painting had ever been.
▪ there is still an illegal but lucrative trade in ivory between africa and south-east asia.
lucrativeadjectivecó lợi, sinh lợi
(especially of a business, job or activity) producing a lot of money
_the merger proved to be very lucrative for both companies.

children.name: goldmine x
children.definition: goldmine/ˈgəʊldmaɪn/ informala small business, especially a shop or restaurant, that produces a very large profit:
examples: mỏ vàng
▪ it’s just a scruffy little beach café, but in summer it’s an absolute goldmine.
▪ i bet that corner shop’s a goldmine.
goldminenounnguồn lợi lớnmỏ vàng
[ s ] something which produceswealthor information
_the archive is a goldmine for historians.

children.name: money-maker x
children.definition: money-makernoun (alsomoney-spinner)món lợi
examples: a product or activity which produces a lot of money

children.name: to make a profit in an unfair way
cash in on x
children.definition: cash in on/ˌkæʃ ˈɪn ɒn/  to make a profit from a situation in a way that iswrongorunfair:
examples: lợi dụng
▪ he’s just cashing in on the fact that his wife is famous.
▪ have you noticed how the record companies cash in on the death of famous pop stars by re-releasing all their old records?

children.name: profit from x
children.definition: profit from/ˈprɒfɪt frɒm, ˈprɒfət frɒmǁˈprɑː-/  to make a profit from abadsituation, instead of trying to help people:
examples: lợi dụng, kiếm lợi từ ( một tình cảnh xấu của người khác )
▪ nobody should be allowed to profit from war and human suffering.
▪ crafty entrepreneurs like harper profited from the ignorance of the masses.

children.name: exploit b2
children.definition: exploit/ɪkˈsloɔɪt/  to make anunfairprofit out ofsomeonewho is in a weaker position than yourself or who seriously needs the things you can sell them, do for them etc:
examples: bóc lột, lợi dụng
▪ measure are being taken to stop employment agencies exploiting foreign workers desperate to find a job.
▪ many ‘new age’ therapists simply exploit the hopes and fears of sick people who would be better off going to their own doctor.
▪ loan sharks who exploit the poor by charging up to 1000% interest per year.

children.name: profiteering x
children.definition: profiteering/ˌprɒfɪˈtɪərɪŋ, ˌprɒfəˈtɪərɪŋǁˌprɑː-/  when someone makes large profits from a bad situation by charging extremely high prices for things that people need to buy:
examples: ▪ the emergency government brought in a special law to prevent hoarding and profiteering.
▪ as food supplies dwindled, complaints against profiteering became more vociferous.

children.name: break even c1
children.definition: hòa vốn
examples: break even/ˌbreɪk ˈiːvən/ [verb phrase]
▪ the company made a small loss last year but this year has managed to break even.
▪ we’ll be just breaking even if we can get an average audience of 300.
break even
to have no profit or loss at the end of especially a business activity
_after paying for our travel costs, webarely(= only just) broke even.

children.name: unprofitable x
children.definition: unprofitable/ʌnˈprɒfɪtəbəl, ʌnˈprɒfətəbəlǁ-ˈprɑː-/  anunprofitablebusinessoractivitydoes not make a profit and is likely to have debts:
examples: không sinh lời
▪ the company says that the publishing side of its division is unprofitable and must be closed down.
▪ unprofitable flight routes have been axed as recession hits the aviation industry.
▪ the bank isn’t likely to lend money to an unprofitable business like yours.
unprofitableadjectivekhông sinh lãi, không mang lợi, không có lời
not making a profit
_rural railway lines risk being axed because they are unprofitable.

children.name: uneconomic x
children.definition: uneconomic/ˌʌniːkəˈnɒmɪk, ˌʌnekə-ǁ-ˈnɑː-/  not making enough profits to be successful or to successfully compete with other companies, industries etc -use this especially when this is a reason for closing the company, industry etc:
examples: không sinh lời
▪ most of the old nationalized industries were labelled ‘uneconomic’ and sold off to private companies.
▪ workers in uneconomic areas of the economy fought hard to keep their factories and mines open.
uneconomicadjective(alsouneconomical)không kinh tế
describes businesses and industries that are not making enough profit or are losing money
_the minister maintained that the coal mines were uneconomic and would have to be closed.
uneconomicadjective(alsouneconomical)không có lợi, không có lời; không có lãi
describes processes or activities that are wasteful and likely to result in a loss of money

children.name: deficit c1
children.definition: deficitnounsố tiền thiếu hụt
examples: the total amount by which money spent is more than money received
_the country is running a balance-of-payments/budget/trade deficitof$250 million.
_theuk's deficitinmanufactured goods fell slightly in the last three months.

children.name: loss c1
children.definition: lossnoun tổn thất, lỗ
examples: [ c ] when a business spends more money than it earns
_the company announced a pre-tax loss of three million pounds.

children.name: margin c2
children.definition: margin/ ˈmɑː.dʒɪn / / ˈmɑːr- /noun(profit)lợi nhuận biên
examples: c2 the profit made on a product or service:
our increased profits are due to improved margins and successful cost control.
using cheap labour increases profit margin.
